[[Bronze Star Medal|Bronze Star]] (US) |laterwork= }} [[Air Chief Marshal]] '''Sir James Donald Innes Hardman''', {{postnominals|country=GBR|size=100|sep=,|GBE|KCB|DFC}} (21 December 1899 – 2 March 1982), known as '''Donald Hardman''', was a senior [[Royal Air Force]] commander. He began his flying career as a [[Fighter aircraft|fighter]] pilot in World War I, achieving nine victories to become an [[Flying ace|ace]]. During World War II, Hardman held senior staff and operational posts. He was [[Chief of Air Force (Australia)|Chief of the Air Staff]] (CAS) of the [[Royal Australian Air Force]] (RAAF) from 1952 to 1954, after which he served as a member of the British [[Air Council]] until retiring in 1958. Born in [[Lancashire]], Hardman joined the [[Royal Flying Corps]] in 1917 and was posted to France the following year. He flew [[Sopwith Dolphin]]s with [[No. 19 Squadron RAF|No. 19 Squadron]], earning the [[Distinguished Flying Cross (United Kingdom)|Distinguished Flying Cross]] for his fighting skills. Between the wars he served with [[No. 31 Squadron RAF|No. 31 Squadron]] in India and [[No. 216 Squadron RAF|No. 216 Squadron]] in Egypt. A [[Wing commander (rank)|wing commander]] at the outbreak of World War II, Hardman was attached to the [[Air Ministry]] for several years before being posted in 1944 to [[South-East Asian theatre of World War II|South East Asia]], where he commanded No. 232 (Transport) Group during the [[Burma campaign]]. He was appointed an [[Officer of the Order of the British Empire]] in 1940 and a [[Companion of the Order of the Bath]] in 1945, and was also [[mentioned in despatches]]. Finishing the war an [[air commodore]], Hardman was Assistant Chief of the Air Staff, Commandant of [[RAF Staff College, Bracknell]], and Air Officer Commanding-in-Chief of [[RAF Home Command|Home Command]], prior to becoming RAAF CAS in January 1952. He was appointed a [[Knight Commander of the Order of the Bath]] the same year. As CAS he was responsible for reorganising the RAAF's [[RAAF area commands|geographically based command-and-control system]] into a functional structure. Returning to Britain, he became [[Air Member for Supply and Organisation]] in May 1954, and was promoted to [[air chief marshal]] the following year. He was raised to [[Knight Grand Cross of the Order of the British Empire]] in January 1958, shortly before his retirement. ==Early life and World War I== [[File:Flight training - 14854331542.jpg|thumb|left|upright=1.2|Sopwith Dolphin fighter|alt=Single-engined military biplane with staggered wings]] Born on 21 December 1899 in [[Oldham, Lancashire]], James Donald Innes Hardman was the son of a master cotton-spinner, also named James, and his wife Wilhelmina. The younger James, known as Donald, was educated at [[Malvern College]].{{cite web|last=McCarthy|first=John|title=Hardman, Sir James Donald Innes (1899–1982)|work= [[Australian Dictionary of Biography]]|url= http://adb.anu.edu.au/biography/hardman-sir-james-donald-innes-12591/text22677|publisher=[[Australian National University]]|accessdate=8 June 2015}}Stephens; Isaacs, ''High Fliers'', pp. 113–115 He began his military career in 1916 as a seventeen-year-old [[Private (rank)|private]] in the [[Artists Rifles]]—part of the [[London Regiment]]—and joined the [[Royal Flying Corps]] (RFC) early the following year.Stephens, ''Australia's Air Chiefs'', pp. 23–24Franks, ''Dolphin and Snipe Aces'', p. 25 Hardman was commissioned a temporary [[second lieutenant]] on 10 May 1917 and confirmed in his rank on 21 July.{{LondonGazette|issue=30100|supp=yes|startpage=5309|date=29 May 1917|accessdate=8 June 2015}}{{cite magazine|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1917/1917%20-%200899.html|title=Royal Flying Corps (Military Wing)|magazine=[[Flight International|Flight]] |date=30 August 1917|page=899|accessdate=10 June 2015}} Prevented initially from seeing combat because of his youth, Hardman was eventually posted to [[No. 19 Squadron RAF|No. 19 Squadron]] on the [[Western Front (World War I)|Western Front]] in February 1918, just as the unit was completing its conversion from [[SPAD S.VII]]s to [[Sopwith Dolphin]]s. He achieved his first aerial victory in May 1918. On 28 September, Hardman was promoted from [[lieutenant]] to temporary [[Captain (armed forces)|captain]], and appointed one of No. 19 Squadron's [[flight commander]]s.{{LondonGazette|issue=30953|startpage=12126|date=15 October 1918|accessdate=8 June 2015}} He scored two "kills" in one [[sortie]] on 30 October 1918, when he led twelve Dolphins escorting [[Airco DH.9|DH.9]] bombers of [[No. 98 Squadron RAF|No. 98 Squadron]] to [[Mons]]; in a dogfight that resulted in the loss of ten British aircraft, Hardman shot down two German [[Fokker D.VII]]s in flames. His "cool judgment and skill in leading" during this action earned him the [[Distinguished Flying Cross (United Kingdom)|Distinguished Flying Cross]]; the award was promulgated on 11 February 1919.{{LondonGazette|city=e|issue=13400|startpage=798|date=11 February 1919|accessdate=8 June 2015}} Hardman's final wartime tally was nine aerial victories. The life expectancy for even an experienced RFC pilot on the Western Front was as little as three weeks;Brent, ''A Century of Military Aviation'', pp. 27–28Robertson, ''The Dream of Civilized Warfare'', p. 106 years later Hardman admitted that he was still surprised he had survived. ==Inter-war years== [[File:RAF Bristol F2B Fighters.jpg|thumb|left|upright=1.2|Bristol Fighters, operated by Nos. 31 and 16 Squadrons between the wars|alt=Two Royal Air Force biplanes in flight]] Hardman's commission was terminated on 8 March 1919; the following year he commenced an economics degree at [[Hertford College, Oxford]].{{LondonGazette|issue=31279|startpage=4574|date=8 April 1919|accessdate=8 June 2015}} On 18 October 1921, he joined the [[Royal Air Force]] (RAF) with a short-service commission as a [[flying officer]], and was posted to India's [[North-West Frontier Province (1901–55)|North-West Frontier]] in 1922.{{cite magazine|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1921/1921%20-%200744.html|title=The Royal Air Force|magazine=Flight |date=10 November 1921|page=744|accessdate=10 June 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://airpower.airforce.gov.au/Contents/About-APDC/About-APDC/Office-of-Air-Force-History/Air-Marshals-of-the-RAAF/140/RAF-Officers-on-Loan.aspx|title=RAF Officers on Loan or Exchange|work=Air Marshals of the RAAF|publisher=[[Department of Defence (Australia)|Department of Defence]]|accessdate=8 June 2015}} He served with [[No. 31 Squadron RAF|No. 31 Squadron]], an [[army cooperation]] unit flying [[Bristol F.2 Fighter|Bristol Fighters]].{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article18234917 |title=The man who will lead the Air Force |newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |date=13 October 1951 |accessdate=10 June 2015 |page=2 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.raf.mod.uk/organisation/31squadron.cfm|title=31 Squadron|publisher=[[Royal Air Force]]|accessdate=10 June 2015}} Hardman's commission was made permanent on 30 September 1925.{{LondonGazette|issue=33094|startpage=6776|date=20 October 1925|accessdate=8 June 2015}} Returning to Britain, he joined [[No. 16 Squadron RAF|No. 16 Squadron]], which operated Bristol Fighters out of [[Old Sarum]], in September 1926.{{cite magazine|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1926/1926%20-%200633.html|title=The Royal Air Force|magazine=Flight |date=2 September 1926|page=557|accessdate=10 June 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.raf.mod.uk/organisation/16squadron.cfm|title=16 Squadron|publisher=Royal Air Force|accessdate=10 June 2015}} Hardman was promoted to [[flight lieutenant]] on 1 July 1927, and attended the Armament and Gunnery School, [[Eastchurch]], in 1928.{{LondonGazette|issue=33290|startpage=4239|endpage=4240|date=1 July 1927|accessdate=8 June 2015}}{{cite magazine|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1928/1928%20-%200203.html|title=The Royal Air Force|magazine=Flight |date=15 March 1928|page=183|accessdate=10 June 2015}} He was then posted to the headquarters staff of [[No. 22 Group RAF|No. 22 (Army Co-operation) Group]], [[Farnborough, Hampshire|South Farnborough]].''The Aeroplane Directory of British Aviation'', p. 412{{cite web|url=http://www.raf.mod.uk/no22traininggroup/aboutus/history.cfm|title=22 (Training) Group|publisher=Royal Air Force|accessdate=26 June 2015}} On 8 July 1930, Hardman married Dorothy Ursula Ashcroft Thompson at [[St George's, Hanover Square|St George's Church]] in [[Hanover Square, London|Hanover Square]], London; the couple had two sons and a daughter. In September the following year, he was posted to [[Heliopolis (Cairo suburb)|Heliopolis]], Egypt, to serve with [[No. 216 Squadron RAF|No. 216 Squadron]].{{cite magazine|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1931/1931%20-%201123.html|title=The Royal Air Force|magazine=Flight |date=16 October 1931|page=1053|accessdate=10 June 2015}} Tasked with bombing and transport duties, the squadron operated [[Vickers Victoria]]s and pioneered the air route from [[Lagos]] to [[Khartoum]] in 1934.Dean, ''The Royal Air Force and Two World Wars'', p. 175Philpott, ''The Royal Air Force'', p. 308 Returning to Britain, Hardman entered the [[RAF Staff College, Andover]], in January 1935.{{cite magazine|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1935/1935%20-%200252.html|title=Royal Air Force intelligence|magazine=Flight |date=31 January 1935|page=128|accessdate=10 June 2015}} After graduating, he was promoted to [[squadron leader]] on 1 February 1936.{{cite magazine|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1936/1936%20-%200346.html|title=The Royal Air Force|magazine=Flight |date=6 February 1936|page=154|accessdate=10 June 2015}}{{LondonGazette|issue=34252|startpage=737|date=4 February 1936|accessdate=8 June 2015}} He served for the next two years as Staff Officer for Armament at No. 23 (Training) Group in [[Grantham]]. Hardman entered the British Army's [[Staff College, Camberley]], in January 1938, and was promoted to [[Wing Commander (rank)|wing commander]] on 1 January 1939.{{cite magazine|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1938/1938%20-%200531.html|title=Royal Air Force appointments|magazine=Flight |date=24 February 1938|page=185|accessdate=10 June 2015}}{{LondonGazette|issue=34586|startpage=61||endpage=62|date=3 January 1939|accessdate=8 June 2015}} ==World War II== {{Quote_box |width=25.8% |align=right |quote=On first meeting the then Air Commodore in his headquarters in Comilla one was immediately aware of an exceptionally dignified bearing, a considerable presence, great humour; there was much leg-pulling and light-hearted banter, the whole atmosphere was very much at ease. Yet one also obtained a remarkably strong impression of "No nonsense"; it was made quite clear that there was a tough job ahead. |source=—Marshal of the Royal Air Force [[John Grandy|Sir John Grandy]], on serving under Hardman at Combat Cargo Task Force, 1944–45 {{cite news|last=Grandy|first=John|authorlink=John Grandy|title=Air Chief Marshal Sir Donald Hardman|work=[[The Times]]|date=15 March 1982|page=10}} }} On the outbreak of World War II, Hardman was sent to France with the Air Component of the [[British Expeditionary Force (World War II)|British Expeditionary Force]]. After the [[Battle of France|Fall of France]] in 1940, he served on the headquarters staff of No. 22 Group and was liaison officer with the British Army's Eastern Command, before taking charge of the Directorate of Military Co-operation—later the Directorate of Operations (Tactical)—at the [[Air Ministry]].{{cite magazine|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1945/1945%20-%202263.html|title=RAF appointments|magazine=Flight |date=15 November 1945|page=540|accessdate=10 June 2015}} He was appointed an [[Officer of the Order of the British Empire]] on 11 July 1940 for "distinguished services rendered in recent operations",{{LondonGazette|issue=34893|supp=yes|startpage=4253|date=9 July 1940|accessdate=8 June 2015}} and [[mentioned in despatches]] on 1 January 1941.{{LondonGazette|issue=35029|supp=yes|startpage=33|endpage=34|date=31 December 1940|accessdate=8 June 2015}} On 1 March 1941, he was promoted temporary [[group captain]].{{LondonGazette|issue=35102|startpage=1448|date=11 March 1941|accessdate=8 June 2015}} Hardman was promoted temporary [[air commodore]] on 1 October 1944,{{LondonGazette|issue=36780|supp=yes|startpage=5073|date=7 November 1944|accessdate=8 June 2015}} and substantive group captain on 1 December.{{LondonGazette|issue=36902|supp=yes|startpage=507|date=19 January 1945|accessdate=8 June 2015}} He was assigned to [[Far East Air Force (Royal Air Force)|Air Command South East Asia]] (ACSEA) as the deputy commander—and RAF component commander—of the Combat Cargo Task Force (CCTF). Comprising RAF, [[Royal Canadian Air Force]], and [[United States Army Air Forces]] elements, CCTF was responsible for supplying the [[Fourteenth Army (United Kingdom)|Fourteenth Army]] in [[Burma Campaign|Burma]].Pearson, ''The Burma Air Campaign'', p. 142 Hardman's final wartime posting, commencing in February 1945, was as [[Air Officer Commanding]] No. 232 (Transport) Group in [[Comilla]], India.{{cite news|title=RAF appointments|work=The Times|date=19 May 1947|page=8}} The group comprised the squadrons that formerly made up the RAF component of CCTF.Pearson, ''The Burma Air Campaign'', p. 165 Hardman described the Burma campaign as "a striking illustration of a fact new in warfare—namely that air power can be used to transport, supply and support ground troops entirely independent of ground channels. This has been South-East Asia's contribution to the art of war."{{cite magazine|last=Probert|first=Henry|title=Air transport and supply in the Burma War|magazine=Royal Air Force Historical Society Journal 22|date=2000 |page=48|url=http://www.rafmuseum.org.uk/documents/Research/RAF-Historical-Society-Journals/Journal-22-Seminar-Air-Transport.pdf|accessdate=26 June 2015}} He was appointed a [[Companion of the Order of the Bath]] on 5 July 1945 for "gallant and distinguished services in connection with the operations in Burma".{{LondonGazette|issue=37161|supp=yes|startpage=3491|date=5 July 1945|accessdate=8 June 2015}} The US government awarded him the [[Bronze Star Medal|Bronze Star]]; permission to wear the decoration was gazetted on 15 March 1946.{{LondonGazette|issue=37501|supp=yes|startpage=1379|endpage=1380|date=15 March 1946|accessdate=8 June 2015}} ==Post-war career== [[File:MALTA0051McCauleyHardman.jpg|thumb|left|upright=1.2|Air Marshal Hardman (left) as RAAF Chief of the Air Staff, with Air Vice Marshal John McCauley, viewing a parade by No. 78 Wing shortly before its departure for garrison duties in Malta, July 1952|alt=Two men in dark military uniforms with peaked caps]] Hardman was promoted to acting [[air vice marshal]] on 1 October 1945.{{LondonGazette|issue=37336|supp=yes|startpage=5385|date=2 November 1945|accessdate=8 June 2015}} He remained in South-East Asia following the cessation of hostilities, taking over as Air Officer in Charge of Administration for ACSEA (later Air Command Far East) in January 1946. After his return to Britain he was appointed to several senior posts in the RAF including, successively, Assistant Chief of the Air Staff (Operations) in May 1947, Commandant of [[RAF Staff College, Bracknell]], in January 1949, and Air Officer Commanding-in-Chief of [[RAF Home Command|Home Command]] in September 1951.{{cite news|title=News in brief|work=The Times |date= 2 April 1955|page= 3}} Hardman's wartime rank of air commodore became substantive on 1 October 1946,{{LondonGazette|issue=37758|supp=yes|startpage=5080|date=11 October 1946|accessdate=8 June 2015}} and this was followed by substantive promotion to air vice marshal on 1 July 1948.{{LondonGazette|issue=38344|supp=yes|startpage=3895|date=2 July 1948|accessdate=8 June 2015}} He was raised to acting [[air marshal]] on 1 October 1951.{{LondonGazette|issue=39520|supp=yes|startpage=2169|date=18 April 1952|accessdate=8 June 2015}} On 14 January 1952, Hardman was appointed [[Chief of Air Force (Australia)|Chief of the Air Staff]] (CAS) of the [[Royal Australian Air Force]] (RAAF), succeeding Air Marshal [[George Jones (RAAF officer)|George Jones]], who had served ten years in the position.Stephens, ''Going Solo'', p. 499 The decision by Australia's [[Prime Minister of Australia|Prime Minister]], [[Robert Menzies]], to appoint an RAF officer caused resentment in the RAAF. This was compounded when Menzies stated his reason as being that there was "no RAAF officer of sufficient age, or operational experience, to take the post of Chief of the Air Staff", which appeared to ignore the wartime records of such figures as [[John McCauley (RAAF officer)|John McCauley]] and [[Frederick Scherger]].Stephens, ''Going Solo'', p. 73 ''[[The Daily Mirror (Australia)|The Daily Mirror]]'' in [[Sydney]] was one of several media outlets to voice a "stern protest" over the matter. Menzies also felt that he could justify the appointment of an outsider on the grounds that the RAAF's [[RAAF area commands|geographically based command-and-control system]] needed reorganisation along functional lines, a system with which a senior RAF member would be familiar. Britain's CAS, Marshal of the Royal Air Force [[John Slessor|Sir John Slessor]], was, somewhat reluctantly, responsible for fulfilling the Australian Government's request for a suitable officer. In putting forward Hardman as the "outstanding candidate" for the Australian post, Slessor tried to avoid what he called "the follies of some years ago", referring to Air Chief Marshal [[Charles Burnett (RAF officer)|Sir Charles Burnett]]'s controversial tenure as CAS on secondment from the RAF early in World War II.Stephens, ''Going Solo'', pp. 73–74 Hardman made two major changes to the structure of the Air Force to streamline command and control: integrating RAAF Headquarters, [[Melbourne]], with the [[Department of Air (Australia)|Department of Air]], and supplanting the geographical area commands with three functional organisations, namely [[RAAF Home Command|Home]] (operational), [[RAAF Training Command|Training]], and [[RAAF Maintenance Command|Maintenance Commands]].Stephens, ''Going Solo'', pp. 75–76Helson, ''Ten Years at the Top'', pp. 293–294 The functional command system has been described by historian Alan Stephens as Hardman's "major legacy to the RAAF". While doing away with the area command structure that had been favoured by Jones, Hardman carried on his predecessor's support for the local aircraft industry.Stephens, ''Going Solo'', pp. 188–190 He also formed a policy agreement with the [[Chief of Navy (Australia)|Chief of the Naval Staff]], Vice Admiral [[John Augustine Collins|Sir John Collins]], covering joint responsibility and cooperation for maritime warfare.Stephens, ''Going Solo'', p. 397 During Hardman's term as CAS, [[No. 78 Wing RAAF|No. 78 (Fighter) Wing]] was re-equipped with RAF [[de Havilland Vampire]] jet fighters to garrison Malta and support British operations in the Mediterranean.Stephens, ''The Royal Australian Air Force'', pp. 221–222 He was appointed a [[Order of the Bath|Knight Commander of the Order of the Bath]] in the [[Queen's Birthday Honours]] promulgated on 5 June 1952,{{LondonGazette|issue=39555|supp=yes|startpage=3009|date=30 May 1952|accessdate=8 June 2015}} and raised to substantive air marshal on 1 July.{{LondonGazette|issue=39586|supp=yes|startpage=3581|date=27 June 1952|accessdate=8 June 2015}} [[File:MALTA0396Hardman.jpg|thumb|right|upright=1.3|Hardman (left) as RAF Air Member for Supply and Organisation, with Air Marshal [[Claude Pelly|Sir Claude Pelly]] (centre), and Admiral [[Louis Mountbatten, 1st Earl Mountbatten of Burma|Lord Louis Mountbatten]] (right) at a ceremonial parade for No. 78 Wing RAAF on its departure from garrison duty in Malta, December 1954|alt=Three men in dark military uniforms with peaked caps]] As a protege of Slessor, Hardman proclaimed: "An air force without bombers isn't an air force". He maintained that the only way to attain "true and enduring air superiority" was by attacking the enemy's vital centres, which included its means of producing fighters.Stephens, ''Going Solo'', pp. 38, 362 He recommended that the RAAF purchase one of Britain's "[[V bomber]]s"—the [[Vickers Valiant]], [[Handley Page Victor]], or [[Avro Vulcan]]—though this never eventuated, and Australia's jet bomber remained the [[English Electric Canberra]] until the long-delayed introduction of the [[General Dynamics F-111C]] in 1973.Stephens, ''The Royal Australian Air Force'', p. 285 Towards the end of his tenure as CAS, Hardman gave an interview in which he criticised [[Australian Army|Army]] and [[Royal Australian Navy|Navy]] operations against a backdrop of continuing interservice rivalry for the defence budget.Dennis et al., ''The Oxford Companion to Australian Military History'', p. 287 He was quoted as saying: "The Air Force in this country, for either defence or offence, is the only force worth while. It can be sent anywhere in the world to the point where it can do most good and be rapidly switched to any other point."{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article134472622 |title=Defence chief's blast |newspaper=[[The News (Adelaide)|The News]] |date=16 February 1954 |accessdate=16 June 2015 |page=1 }} In contrast to the initial disquiet at his appointment, upon his departure from Australia Hardman was described by ''[[The Age]]'' as "the outstanding CAS in the RAAF's history", a "brilliant organiser", and a "master of the theory of air power". He was succeeded by Air Marshal McCauley on 18 January 1954. Hardman returned to Britain on the [[SS Himalaya|SS ''Himalaya'']], and joined the British [[Air Council]] as [[Air Member for Supply and Organisation]] on 1 May 1954, succeeding Air Chief Marshal [[John Whitworth-Jones|Sir John Whitworth-Jones]].Stephens, ''Going Solo'', p. 206{{LondonGazette|issue=40163|supp=yes|startpage=2618|date=4 May 1954|accessdate=8 June 2015}} In December, he represented the Air Council at No. 78 Wing's farewell parade in Malta, reminding the personnel gathered that he had been present at the wing's march through Sydney in July 1952, prior to its departure for the Mediterranean.{{cite magazine|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1954/1954%20-%203270.html|title=No. 78 Wing returns home|magazine=Flight |date=10 December 1954|page=847|accessdate=10 June 2015}} He was promoted to [[air chief marshal]] on 1 April 1955.{{LondonGazette|issue=40442|supp=yes|startpage=1929|date=1 April 1955|accessdate=8 June 2015}} In July 1956, he presented a Squadron Standard to his old unit, No. 19 Squadron.{{cite magazine|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1956/1956%20-%200990.html|title=No. 19 Sqn Standard|magazine=Flight |date=20 July 1956|page=136|accessdate=10 June 2015}} That October, he presided over the inquiry into the [[Avro Vulcan#Accidents and incidents|fatal crash]] of Vulcan ''[[1956 London Heathrow Avro Vulcan crash|XA897]]'' at [[Heathrow Airport]] after its maiden round-the-world flight, the only survivors of the six crew members being the pilot and Air Marshal [[Harry Broadhurst|Sir Harry Broadhurst]].McLelland, ''Vulcan'', pp. 96–98 Hardman was succeeded as Air Member for Supply and Organisation by Air Chief Marshal [[Walter Dawson (RAF officer)|Sir Walter Dawson]] on 1 January 1958, and was raised to [[Order of the British Empire|Knight Grand Cross of the Order of the British Empire]] the same day.{{LondonGazette|issue=41266|supp=yes|startpage=7593|date=31 December 1957|accessdate=8 June 2015}} He retired from the RAF on 29 January.{{LondonGazette|issue=41268|supp=yes|startpage=9|date=1 January 1958|accessdate=8 June 2015}} ==Later life== Hardman joined the board of New Electronic Products Ltd in May 1959.{{cite news|title=Business Changes|work=The Times |date=19 May 1959|page= 14}} In February 1963, he succeeded Air Chief Marshal [[Douglas Evill|Sir Douglas Evill]] as the [[RAF Benevolent Fund]]'s honorary county representative for [[Hampshire]].{{cite magazine|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1963/1963%20-%200324.html?|title=Air Force, Naval and Army Flying News|magazine=Flight International|date=28 February 1963|page=308|accessdate=10 June 2015}} Sir Donald Hardman died on 2 March 1982, while holidaying in [[Estoril]], Portugal, and was survived by his wife and children.{{cite news|date=9 March 1982|title=A C/M Sir D. Volume II: Rearmament 1930–1939|location=Barnsley, South Yorkshire |publisher=Pen and Sword Books|isbn=978-1-84415-391-6}} *{{cite book | last= Robertson| first= Linda Raine| year= 2003| title= The Dream of Civilized Warfare: World War I Flying Aces and the American Imagination| location = Minneapolis | publisher= [[University of Minnesota Press]] | isbn = 0-8166-4270-2 }} *{{cite book|last=Stephens| first=Alan| year=1995| title=Going Solo: The Royal Australian Air Force 1946–1971|location=Canberra|publisher=[[Australian Government Publishing
